Tom Holland's entry into both Marvel and as the new Spider-Man is, in my humble opinion, one of the most welcome and fun entries in superhero history, adding the teenage magic and sharp humor that a Spider-Man movie deserves. He's one of my current favorite heroes in the MCU, and every time I see him on screen, it seems like a melody is playing that not all is lost and that Marvel's ability to "get there" has never seemed so easy.

⭐ Spoiler Alert – This review contains mild thematic discussion.

Rewatching Spiderman: Homecoming reminded me of how ambitious yet uneven Marvel’s first solo entry for this version of Peter Parker truly is. The film succeeds in its youthful energy, sharp pacing, and strong casting, but it occasionally struggles to capture the emotional and moral depth that defines Spiderman’s character at his core.

At times, the story leans more toward lighthearted teen comedy than a meaningful hero’s journey. The humor often overshadows the weight of Peter’s responsibilities, making his path feel more like a high school adventure than a defining chapter in his life as a hero. Still, the movie’s tone is undeniably fun and relatable, offering an accessible entry point for younger audiences.

The high school setting works well in illustrating Peter’s double life, though the balance between his normal struggles and heroic duties isn’t always consistent. Moments that could explore his internal conflict are often resolved too quickly, leaving emotional growth somewhat underdeveloped.

Tony Stark’s mentorship adds an interesting layer, but the dynamic sometimes feels more controlling than collaborative. Peter’s independence—one of Spiderman’s defining traits—takes a backseat to Stark’s oversight, which limits the character’s development.

The portrayal of Aunt May is refreshing in warmth and energy, though some may miss the traditional wisdom and gravity associated with the character. Likewise, omitting certain familiar origin details makes this version of Peter feel more dependent on others than self-made.

Michael Keaton’s performance as the Vulture is easily one of the highlights. His grounded and believable portrayal adds much-needed tension and humanity to the story, giving the film its emotional center.

The final act delivers the strongest material, bringing back the sense of heart and courage that defines Spiderman. It shows Peter’s selflessness and his growth into the hero he’s meant to be—reminding us why he remains one of Marvel’s most beloved characters.

Overall, Spiderman: Homecoming is an entertaining but imperfect chapter in the web-slinger’s cinematic journey. Its humor and youthful charm make it enjoyable, but some creative choices keep it from reaching the emotional depth and legacy the character deserves. Still, thanks to Tom Holland’s enthusiasm and Michael Keaton’s compelling performance, it remains a fun and heartfelt entry in the Marvel universe.

LAYMAN REVIEW: 7.9/10
Tom holland playing this character makes it feel like spiderman is literally just a teenager compared to the other spider men really fun watch

Critics Consensus:
Fresh, funny, and full of youthful energy, Spider-Man: Homecoming brings the wall-crawler back to his roots with a lighthearted spirit and a much-needed sense of fun. Free from another origin story, this reboot swings confidently into the Marvel Cinematic Universe with style and heart.

Tom Holland delivers a charming and authentic take on Peter Parker—an eager, relatable teenager trying to balance high school life with superhero responsibilities. Michael Keaton’s Vulture stands out as one of the MCU’s most grounded and menacing villains, giving the film real dramatic weight. Director Jon Watts keeps the tone breezy and fast-paced, blending superhero spectacle with a John Hughes–style coming-of-age story.

While it may not reach the emotional highs of Raimi’s classics, Spider-Man: Homecoming succeeds by focusing on character, humor, and heart. It’s a smart, spirited reboot that reminds audiences why Spider-Man remains one of cinema’s most beloved heroes.

I mean come on, this is peak, like this is my freakin comfort movie. This is one of the movies I could watch like literally every day! If I could, not tryna be weird but if I could, I would marry this freaking movie but anyways solid 4👌

Spider-Man Homecoming was the true beginning to Tom Hollands titular character living and operating in the MCU after years of anticipation. Covering the events before, during and mostly after civil war but it struggles, like the character himself, to stand on its own. 

The film is fun enough, with great performances and Chemistry from our new Peter Parker and his relationship with Iron Man as a real high point — unfortunately, outside of that, no one really stands out. Michael Keaton portrays the Vulture and is visually interesting but, as will become the trend in the sequel, feels more like an Iron Man villain and struggles to build any meaningful relationship with our Protagonist. While Peters personal life does lead to more of a connection to Vulture, it falls mostly flat and feels mainly present to have one twist at the end that feels unearned. Spidey is still rocking his Iron Man created Civil War suit with new AI: Karen. The learning montage of Peter and Karen does make for some funny moments of banter between them but feels less than necessary. Visually, the film relies heavily on CGI for the Spidey. While this allows for more expressive eyes, it makes the character feel less grounded than previous Spider-Men, like Andrew Garfield’s portrayal, which incorporated more practical action and swinging sequences and real suit without constant visual enhancements. Speaking of action, this movie has a fair amount but aside from a small moment on the ferry, really lacks the spectacle you’d expect from both Spider-Man and the MCU. 

When he first swung into Civil War, I was excited. The Russos wrote him well enough and funny enough that I could get past being less than excited about the visual design on the suit. But the first solo outing for the wall crawler left me wanting more, from the story, the characters and the visuals. His relationship with Tony Stark is fun and interesting but it’s not enough to carry the film, thankfully the threequel nails it later on.
Spiderman homecoming is really underated this film is one the re-watch able MCU films.

Bad characterization of Spider-man, and Iron-Man being his mentor is unnecessary.
